elements.text: Name of second Frankish dynasty of kings. Name taken from the Latin name for Charles-Carolus.
A noble who ruled a county or other small region during Charlemagne's time. Later a high ranking noble.
A frontier area along the border of a country, especially one subject to attack and needing strong defense.
In the Middle Ages, the military ruler of a march.
Large district in central Italy ruled by Popes from 775-1870.
A room in a monastery for writing or copying manuscripts.
Literally a man's price or worth. The price determined the amount of compensation to be paid.
WORLD HISTORY â€“ UNIT 3: THE MEDIEVAL WORLD
TRANSITION: THE CONTINENT AND NEW INVASIONS

The eighth through the eleventh centuries brought many changes in
 European politics, economics, culture, and religion.
 Invasions were less frequent and more highly concentrated,
 individual kingdoms began to emerge as leaders, a new empire
 was being established on the continent, and the feudal system
 began to take hold and to grow throughout medieval
 Europe.

In this section, you will
 study some of the key men and events that played a role in,
 and at times caused, these changes. You will study the rise
 and fall of Charlemagne's empire, the England of King Alfred
 the Great, and the new wave of invasions that threatened
 Europe.
Here are your goals for this lesson:
Identify significant events in the reign of Charlemagne.
Recognize the role of the Vikings and Magyars in the decline of the Roman Empire.

The most important
 European development in Europe at this time was the rise of
 Charlemagne and his empire. During his reign the Frankish
 empire was expanded, government was stabilized, education and
 learning were encouraged, and the power of the Catholic
 church was strengthened and extended.

At this same time, in
 England, culture and learning were flourishing in the
 monastic centers. The political situation was relatively
 stable because the king, Alfred the Great, was strong and
 able.
. After the death of Clovis in

, the Frankish kingdom had been divided
 among his four sons. Constant disputes and civil wars
 resulted in a three-way division of the kingdom in the seventh century. This division established
 the kingdoms of Neustria, Austrasia, and Burgundy. The
 Frankish kings of the seventh century
 did very little. For this reason, they became known as the
 Do-Nothing-Kings. The real power in each kingdom was the
 Mayor of the Palace. The genealogy shows the succession of
 the these Mayors, or Arnulfian Mayors as they are sometimes
 called.
Click on button to see chart.

Pepin, Mayor of the
 Palace in Austrasia, reunited Austrasia and Neustria and gave
 himself the title of "leader and prince of the Franks". By
 doing so he established himself as an hereditary ruler.
 Pepin's son, Charles Martel, sometimes called, "the Hammer"
 became Mayor of the Palace in

and strengthened the frontiers, put
 down the Muslim attacks, and protected Christian missionaries
 from the barbarians and the Arian Christians.

Charles' son, Pepin the
 Short, ruled from
. He ruled as Mayor of the Palace until

when he was elected king by the
 nobles. Pepin asked the Pope to anoint him king and
 officially declare the end of the reign of the
 Do-Nothing-Kings. The Pope agreed and in

, Pepin the Short was anointed king.
 Pepin defeated the Lombards in Italy in

and gave
 some of the lands to the Pope. This land gift is known as the
 Donation of Pepin and became the

, Pepin's two sons, Charles and
 Carloman, took the throne. By

,
 Charles was the sole ruler and reigned over his Frankish
 empire until

. Charles was the first
 and greatest of the

kings. He became known as Charles the Great, or Charlemagne.
 Charlemagne was an able military leader. His military and
 religious goal was to unite the Germanic tribes into a single
 Christian state. Charlemagne battled the Lombards, annexed
 their land at the Pope's behest, and gave himself the title,
 King of the Lombards, in

. He battled the tribes
 between the Rhine and the Elbe rivers for nearly thirty
 years. The captured tribes were given the choice of
 Christianity or death. Charlemagne conquered the Avars in the
 east, and eliminated them from the region of the Danube River. He attacked the
 Muslims in Spain in

and, after
 setbacks and the loss of many lives, captured the northeast
 section in

a significant event in European history
 took place. On Christmas Day of that year, Pope Leo III
 crowned Charlemagne, the "Emperor of the Romans." This was an
 attempt to reestablish the Roman Empire with Charlemagne as
 its emperor and with the full support of the Roman Church
 behind him. This angered the Byzantine Empire in the east
 which believed it had a claim to Rome as the remaining part
 of the original empire. This event also reinforced the power
 of the church in government affairs. In effect, the church
 had crowned and approved Charlemagne. This question of
 political power of the church over temporal rulers became
 more serious in the centuries to follow.

Charlemagne's government was well organized
 and stable because of a carefully planned check system.
 Charlemagne appointed

who were usually wealthy
 men of noble families. The count ruled over a county together
 with the bishop or archbishop of that county. Charlemagne
 appointed

to rule over a group of counties.
 Finally, Charlemagne appointed agents known as

"messengers of God," who went out in pairs to
 visit the counties each year. These messengers checked the
 local courts and reported the state of the empire to
 Charlemagne. The frontier areas, or

as they
 were called, were ruled by margraves who were counts and
 military men. These buffer zones surrounded most of the
 empire.

Charlemagne's capital was
 at Aix-la-Chapelle, (the modern city of Aachen, Germany). The legal
 system of the empire was primarily the ancient Germanic law
 that retained the compensation or

and the
 trial by ordeal. The major difference was the Christian
 emphasis added to this law, and the Christian interpretation
 of the law.

Europe and Charlemagne's
 empire were isolated economically. Charlemagne restored roads
 and bridges, but very little trade passed over them. The
 Muslims controlled the trade routes to the East and the
 shipping routes of the Mediterranean, making an economy based
 on trade impossible. Minimal trade was carried on between
 provinces. Little money was coined because little was
 used.

Landowners were warriors
 first, and they thought of their lands only as a means of
 financing wars. This attitude led to the decline of the
 agricultural method, and to poor living and working
 conditions for the lower class.

Click on
 button to see chart.

The reign of Charlemagne
 is distinguished as a time of culture and learning; therefore
 the term "Carolingian Renaissance" is sometimes applied to
 Charlemagne's reign. The buildings and churches of the
 capital city at Aix-la-Chapelle reflected both Roman and
 Byzantine influences. For some structures he imported columns
 from Rome and Ravenna.

Click on
 button to see chart.

Charlemagne established
 centers of learning and sought out famous scholars to teach
 the secular clergy and laity as well as the children. He also
 established libraries and a famous

at Tours so that ancient manuscripts could be preserved and
 copied by monks. The greatest scholar to Charlemagne's court
 was the English monk, Alcuin of York (

), who
 established a palace school, the

at Tours,
 and who directed most of the educational activity of the
 empire.

Charlemagne issued laws
 ordering the monastic and cathedral schools to provide better
 education for the clergy. He also established parish schools
 where none existed. To insure observation of these laws he
 sent out the

to report on the progress
 of the schools. Some of these schools survived and became the
 basis of medieval universities. Little Carolingian literature
 survives. What remains suggests that the Carolingian empire
 produced little, if any, good literature.

,
 Charlemagne had his son, Louis the Pious, crowned emperor. As
 soon as Charlemagne died, the empire began to collapse. Louis
 the Pious was a weak leader and could not hold together the
 vast territory. He divided the empire among his three sons
 who immediately began to fight over their allotted lands. The
 two younger sons, Louis the German and Charles the Bald,
 joined forces against their elder brother, Lothar (or Lothair), who was
 then emperor. In

, the younger
 brothers formalized their union by the Strasbourg Oaths.

by the Treaty of Verdun, the empire was
 redivided into three kingdoms. The western kingdom, or West
 Frankland, went to Charles the Bald. The eastern kingdom, or
 East Frankland, went to Louis the German. These two kingdoms
 formed the basis for what would become modern France and
 modern Germany centuries later. The middle kingdom, which was
 a narrow strip of land extending from the North Sea to the
 middle of Italy, went to Lothar. This narrow strip between
 the two other kingdoms was a source of constant warfare.
 Sections of this strip have been the source of conflict
 between France and Germany since that time.

Civil wars and poor
 leadership weakened the empire to such an extent that it
 could no longer resist foreign invasions. The last
 Carolingian emperor, Charles the Fat, son of Louis the
 German, was deposed in

because he
 had not been strong against the Viking raiders. Charles the
 Simple, the last Carolingian king died in
Match these vocabulary terms to their definitions. Match the items in the left column to the items in the right column.
name of the second Frankish dynasty of kings
an area along the border of a country, especially one subject to attack
a room in a monastery for writing or copying manuscripts
literally, a man's price or worth
large district in central Italy ruled by Popes from 775-1870
a noble who ruled a county in Charlemagne's time
in the Middle Ages, the military ruler of a march
The Frankish kings of the seventh century were called
Charlemagne was crowned emperor on ________ in the year 800 by Pope Leo III.
Charlemagne's people that were assigned to travel in pairs through the empire checking on courts and the state of the empire were called:
The time of great learning during Charlemagne's reign was the time known as the Carolingian
The greatest scholar brought to Charlemagne's court came from:
The Treaty of Verdun was made in:

The decline of
 Charlemagne's empire opened the way for new barbarian
 invasions, just as the decline of the Western Roman Empire
 opened the way for the earlier barbarian invasions. The
 invaders came from the north as the Germanic
 Scandinavian tribes began to push southward and from the east as the Slavs and the Magyars
 began to move toward the west. The Muslims also
 continued their invasions from the south.

. The
 Germanic invaders, the Vikings or Norsemen, had the greatest
 impact. The Vikings from the areas now known as Norway,
 Sweden, and Denmark invaded coastal territories from Russia
 to England, down the Frankish coastal areas, around the
 Spanish peninsula, and into the Mediterranean as far as Rome.
 Evidence has been found showing Viking presence through
 Russia by land to Constantinople. About the year

, the Norwegian Vikings reached North
 America by way of Iceland and Greenland.

The Vikings were skilled
 seamen who attacked silently and quickly. They killed men and
 children, looted and burned churches and monasteries, and
 carried off the women. The attack was so swift that little
 could be done to fight them.

After Charlemagne's
 death, Viking raids along the coast of West Frankland
 accelerated. In

Charles the Simple
 allowed Rollo and his band of Vikings to settle on the
 northwest coast. This group remained; they called themselves
 Normans and their territory Normandy. They set up a
 government and became Christians. Rollo was baptized Robert
 and became the first Duke of Normandy.

In Ireland, the Vikings
 destroyed many of the monasteries, killing the monks,
 destroying the libraries, and carrying off the treasures. The
 Vikings invaded the Irish for nearly two hundred years from
 the late eighth century to the late tenth century.

In England, the Vikings
 found greater opposition. They raided England first in

. In the ninth century the Danish
 Vikings invaded the north of England. They established
 themselves in Northumbria and north of the Thames River. They
 met defeat in

at the hands of Alfred
 the Great and entered into an agreement known as the
 Danelaw.
In the footsteps of the Vikings

.
 In the eighth and ninth centuries, the Slavic tribes began
 frequent attacks on east Frankland. Late in the ninth century
 an Asiatic tribe, the Magyars, began a devastating march
 through eastern Europe. Their cruelty reminded Europeans of
 the dreaded Attila. The Magyars were sometimes called
 Hungarians because of their ancestral ties to the Huns.

The Magyars drove the
 Slavs out from north of the Danube River and settled there. This
 land has been referred to as Hungary ever since. Eventually
 Poland, parts of Italy, and Bavaria were taken. The Magyars
 did not attack Constantinople, but forced the empire to pay
 them tribute.
In 911 Charles the Simple allowed Vikings to settle in what was later called:
